Entry.1: Should have left London this morning but did not do so. Met Archie Allan took some photos of Westminster etc & had dinner at Portland Hotel Oxford Circus with Mrs Allan & family. In the afternoon went to Wandsworth saw Foster, McMeikin & Weidon returned to town & had dinner.
Entry.2: Left at 7.50 am train from Victoria reached Boulogne 1.20 pm stayed at Hotel de Paris Ronald & Dos, went Visiting.
Entry.3:
Took train to Etaples then goods train to Abbeville & then passenger to Amiens. Arrived there 6.30 pm had tea & then got a car to Contay, glad to get back to the Battn. 7 or 8 letters from home awaiting me.

23/5/17

Lt Douglas has returned. He is 2nd in command to me, early morning parade a strain. I am in charge of the working up of the men for the Bge. Sports to take place on the
Entry.5: Have a good number of men training both morning & afternoon for the Sports, running with them to get condition. Country here looks beautiful weather is perfect.
Entry.6: Training in progress, bit of a strain coming down to parade. A Coy & D have a combined mess.
Entry.7: Very hot day so sat men down in the shade & lectured men on various subjects, getting rather good at the lecturing game now.
Entry.8: Church parade in the morning, went for a ride with Doc. 18th Battn had their try outs in the afternoon for the Bge Sports, some good races were put up.
Entry.9: Sat on Court martial all day with Major Briers & Lieut Hill at 20th Btn H.Q. Phubernple did 4 cases, wrote practically all day.
Entry.10:
Court martial again today, finished up all cases by 4 pm. Rode back to Contay with Hill. Fixed up heats for try outs taking place

to-morrow. Lieut Bilcher & Sgt Brittes left for England to get decorations conferred by the King.
Entry.11: Had sports for try out, everything went off without a hitch. Some very good finishes, not to many entries for the boxing. Played game of football against a T.M.B. lost 11 – 3, very good game played as wing, ¾ condition rather good.
Entry.12: Duty Coy only a few men on Parade, spent day in fixing up representations for Bge sports.
Entry.13: Went to a demonstration at H.I. wood stokes barrage put up was very fine, six guns firing. 30 – 40 shells in the air at once, got some photos of bursts. Heats of boxing fought, some good fights.
Entry.14:
Beginnings of Bge Sports finals in boxing fought this morning, very good goes. Page a M.G. & Lee H Coy put up a splendid show. Page was very nearly knocked out, down 3 times in 1st round,

fought 6 2 minutes in the afternoon, had horse show at H.I. wood, rather slow. Sgt Dunn’s mare won the steeple chase.
Entry.15: Spent morning fixing up sports ground, looked very well when finished. I was starter & general judge etc. they went off very well at end 18th won from 19th by 1 point, scores were 12 – 11. Saw Chappie at night got Permission from Col to go to Amiens with Chappie.
Entry.16: Col intimated that I was to go on a Court of enquiry instead of going to Amiens, would not tell me definitely, very unsatisfactory, should have kept his word of night before or given a definite no & reasons. Thinking less of him every day & all the others the same. In a months time this Battn will be all to pieces through him. Concert tonight at stadium. Concert quite good. On Court of inquiry all day.
Entry.17: Still on inquiry on men absent without leave. Coy & other officers went out to training ground at H.I. wood.
Entry.18: Drill in the morning on own ground, fixed up cricket match for afternoon with
Entry.19:
Battn. We went in first & made 136, 18th made 141 & then we went in again & made 78. I took 7 wks for 33 runs.

7/6/17

Spent day at wood. Coy in attack, a beautiful view from the T Ground A & B Coy played cricket match in the afternoon. B Coy won by 100 runs.
Entry.20: T Ground again watch bet C & D Coy. C won by 30 runs, rather a good match.
Entry.21: Still training, have a very lively mess.
Entry.22: Church service in morning, cricket match against 18th Battn, lost. Photos from London arrived, very good indeed.
Entry.23:
Training again, beautiful weather, wrote letter home to Dad

giving details of Bullecourt. Walker Johnson joined up in my Coy.
Entry.24: Duty Coy today went to wood. Spent time in working the Ba & stroud range finder.
Entry.25: Half holiday went for walk with Hinds, lovely day played football match against 1st Div Artillery, won by 24 – 3. Jones went on leave took one of my photos with him.
Entry.26: Felt Contay 6.30 am marched to Puchvillers via Toutencourt entrained & moved to Bapaume via Beaumont-Hamel, Thiepval, Achiet-le-Grand, Bihucourt, marched to camp between Sapignies & Biefvillers. Camp very well laid out. Cricket pitch & tennis courts quite close. Battn mess started. Bennett joined me as a platoon commander.
Entry.27: Commenced parades 7 – 7.30 am 9 – 12.30 pm, play cricket etc in afternoon.
Entry.28: Drill in the morning played 20th Batt cricket, lost by an innings & 40 runs.
Entry.29: Church parade in the morning went across to 3rd C.C.S. in afternoon, saw nurse Kelly who came across on the Euripides, played a set of tennis with 2 of the nurses. Allan & Hinds with me.
Entry.30: Parades again 5 – 6.30 am, 8 – 11 am. Coy in attack. Walker joined L guns & has friend Scott. He does not seem to mind the carrying & work. Chappie came over & went for a ride.
Entry.31: Had early morning parade & then rained. On Court martial all day at 20th Battn H.Q.
Entry.32: Usual parades before dinner guest night Chappie could not turn up. Harheck did. He is I think infatuated with a French girl in Amiens bur as I told him it will pass off.
Entry.33:
Practiced attack in the morning 2 pts against the other, great interest shown, went to a demonstration of wireless very rotten lecture, man who lectured spent a night

with us when we were in E Camp Bernafay Wood, talk a lot does not know much.
Entry.34: Attach again Hall used an improvised tank, men took to like children although we are only five miles from the line. Went to 18 Batt mess, give lectures to N.C.O.’s very night they are becoming quite keen on their work. Had an alarm just as I got back from mess, stood for ½ hr nothing doing 19th Batt was first in the Brigade.
Entry.35: Much colder today, good day for work, front very quite.
Entry.36:
Church parade in morning, presentation of prizes by General Smythe for Bge sports. Went for a ride to Peronne with Chappie, Morgan, Harbeck & Belcher. On way could see what wonderful observation Fritz had over our line before he retired. Passed through Bapaume, Beaulencourt, Le Transloy, Sailly-Sallisel

town knocked about like Bapaumes about same size would be very pretty in natural times, river runs through town. Put in for Paris leave.
Entry.37: Drilling in morning. Coy much improved still a long way to go. Today is the 2nd anniversary of the Battn departure from Sydney.
Entry.38: Cold & windy. Lt Hall & Bennett left with 80 O.R. for Martinpuich to do loading work until they return will not have much to do.
Entry.39:
Played 18 Batt cricket on their ground at the finish of the days play had 62 runs to get & 2 wks to fall a good game fielding on both sides was good.

28/6/17

Percy Jones arrived back from leave. Had splendid time & looks very well. His people live at Teddington on the Thames. Storm passed over camp at 9 pm. Blew down four tents. A move is close at hand probably going north. Cricket match finished

by a win to the 18th by 3 runs, played officers of the 18th afterwards, we won by 30 runs. I got 51 & in
Entry.41: Drill in morning. In afternoon had preparations made for a Bge review. G Holman & Birdwood did not come. Bge turned out very well. Went to Bancourt for demonstration of a pt attacking strong point. Tommy platoon turned out well, 48th Division.
Entry.42: Rained all day. Holman & Birdwood saw all officers of Bge, but no parade, gave a short speech not much enthusiasm shown, decorations given by Birdwood.
Entry.43: Church parade in the morning, played match against T.M.B. in afternoon, won by an innings & 150 runs. 18th beat 20th.
Entry.44: Went to Martinpinch via Le Sars cutting. Valley is deserted. Hall & Bennnett are having a good time saw 18th died on top of a bug-out opposite old Bge H.Q. Bd of inquiry on no man.
Entry.45: Usual parades in the morning had practice match, weather cool.
Entry.46: In afternoon played match against % F.F. won by an innings & 45 runs.
Entry.47: Went to field firing range at -Thilloy in afternoon, camped there for the night joined by Hall & Bennett from Martinfinch went for a walk over the trenches in front of Beaulencourt & Le Transloy. Had look at these so many times in December when occupied by Fritz.
Entry.48: Carried out field firing during morning one pt at a time finished by 11.30 am, had dinner & moved back to camp, played tennis with Bge.
Entry.49:
Practiced an attack by the Battn, Coy worked well went for a ride in the afternoon to look over ground for the Div attack. Passed through Bancourt, Reincourt-les-Bapaume, Villers-au-Flos & Beaulencourt, attack to be made on the last named village.

The 1st Anzac corps have been turned into assault troops for the purpose of exploiting a success thus the specific training.
Entry.50: Rained all day no church parade so took opportunity of sleeping in which I did with good result. Percy Jones went to 5th T.B.
Entry.51: Left camp at 5.0 am & went to Villers-au-Flos attack on Beaulencourt was not a huge success owing to two of my platoons losing directions arrived back in camp about 6 pm tired out.
Entry.52: Allan took company to Thilloy to watch some field firing practices. I was on a court of inquiry at Martinfrich most of the day. Had some cricket practice in afternoon. Fritz shelled Baupaume at the beginning of the Albert Rd in damage, shells dropped just in front as we arrived at Baupaume. Took photo of 15" shell.
Entry.53:
Drill in morning in afternoon had Page review & won

by officers at the Bge Horse show were given out. After parade played 17 Batt cricket only finished 1 innings each 17 made 145 & we 141 finish to-morrow.
Entry.54: Lecture by Major Conrick of 6th F.A. on venereal disease, excellent Lecture. Seems that a campaign is being started about time cricket finished in our favour by 19 runs this puts 17 A.M.C. 18 & 19 on a level for the Cup.
Entry.55: Attack on Laupart wood, went off very well platoon working much better than last time weather warm & dry Storkey returned to Battn.
Entry.56: Went to a demonstration at Avenly Model platoon sections exercised according to their name – some of the finest drill I have seen, stopped for dinner with Segal went for a swim in L’Anere afterwards. Returned to Baupaume for motor bus.
Entry.57: Sunday, went to Communion in the morning played A.M.C. in the afternoon won by 12 runs very exciting game, near end 5th A.M.C. had 16 runs to get & 5 wks to fall we finished by getting the last 5 wks for 4 runs. I took 5 wks for 14 runs. Sam Chappie & Lyle Buchanman during afternoon.
Entry.58: Practiced platoon in the work I had seen at the Corps School. Hall has gone to H.Q. as L.G. Officer.
Entry.59: On Courtmartial in the martial. Rec letter from Frank Burke. He is going to Australia.
Entry.60: Drill as usual in the morning played M.G. Company in the afternoon, last match of 1st round, won by 80 runs. This puts the 4 Battn teams level. Langham, McBreckin, Kirke & Reid returned. Langham & Reid came home.
Entry.61:
Had sports on the afternoon went off very well men took a

great interest in them. In the drilling competition I entered 2 teams from the Coy & obtained 1 & 2nd places. The drill & marching was very fine indeed.
Entry.62: Drill in morning went out on night manoeuvres, reached places alright arrived back at 1.0 am.
Entry.63: No drill today owing to last nights work, rode to Arras with Morgan. Large town about the size of Amiens. Some very fine buildings some civil inhabitants still there. Had afternoon tea in officers club. A small botanical garden run by the E.F.C, met Hutchinson there who did engineering at the Varsity & lived in Mouchen Rd, Mosman.
Entry.64:
Passes arrived for Hinds & myself to go to Paris, departed toutismite via Albert by car, Amiens & Paris by Train, arrived at 8.30 pm stayed at Regina Hotel near La Louvre & 

overlooking the Tuileries. Went out to find a friend of Hinds, Suzanne Vincent, 25 Rue de Paquette. She was out, will go again to-morrow, passed over same railway 16 months ago on my way to Thiennes from Marseilles.
Entry.65: Left Hotel early went to Miss Vincent she was out returned to Hotel & found her, spent day in going round Paris did 3 hours in a taxi sawLa Bastille, Louvre, Arc de Triomph, Bois de Boulougne, Bois de Vinviennes, went on Seine to Charenton, saw junction of Seine & Marne. Had dinner at Restaurant du Ambassadeurs, saw play from Table. Dinner & theatre combined. Returned to Hotel early left Hinds with Suzanne very much in love with one another, no place for me.
Entry.66:
Met Suzanne, visited Jardine des Plants, had dinner at

Les Ambassadeurs, went to Versailles, saw over palace & grounds. One room nothing but pictures of the great battles won by France, such battles as Agincourt & Waterloo are absent. Suzanne is an extremely beautiful woman not so much in looks but in manner. A common sense, she is well educated & very interesting to talk to & despises the gay life of the average Parisienne, & looks upon it as the cause of the downfall of the French nation. She & Hinds are fond of one another & I would like him to marry her should he make up his mind to do so. I shall try to keep his skin whole. The people of Paris look thin & weak due no doubt to the gay life they lead. This means no children or weak ones & the the final result obvious. The thinking Frenchman I spoke to one & he said that

the French were only holding on. Russia would give no help & looked forward to peace being an agreement & not final victory. French people are very unsettled & another revolution likely. Paris is as bad if not worse than London for girls on the street.
Entry.67:
Met Suzanne early went to Sacré-Coéur take a lift up the face of a cliff to the church. This situated in Montmartre & gives a wonderful view of the whole of Paris.

Then went to Les Invalides & Napoleon’s tomb, really magnificent, contains tombs of Napoleons great generals. Hundreds of flags in the temple all captured by Nap. in his wars. 1 British Union Jack among them. Decorations of a combination of brass & steel work. Tomb is of marble & presented by Czar of Russia.
Entry.68: Rather an unique day. Went with Miss Vincent to the Trocadéro & La Louvre, had dinner & saw her off to Rouen. Had dinner with Hinds at Maxims Restaurant. We went there early, girls came in & the game started. They took up places from which they could see all the men in the room & then it became a battle. The success of the most beautiful some were very fine girls. However we got out safely. Give the. Went to Music Hall in the Champs d’Elyées met two girls, had a drink. Well dressed so decided to make a night of it. I arrived back at the Hotel at 2.30 am after some fine experiences -------. The girl I went with was well educated & we had as far as my French would allow, a long talk about things which I hope may do some good.
Entry.69:
Did some shopping in the morning, left Paris by 1.20 pm arrived

at Amiens. Passed Division on the move. Continued on to Calais via Boulogne, stopped there the night.
Entry.70: Had swim in Channel, stung by blue-bottles, left by 11.20 am train for Hazelbrouch, found Div had not yet arrived, stayed the night at rest camp.
Entry.71: Caught train to St Omer & arrived there just after the battn had detrained followed them out to Arques, billets fair.
Entry.72: Had an inspection. Walker Johnson looks well. Glad to get back to the Battn, feels like home, leave for 2 days training to-morrow.
Entry.73: Left Arques 3.45 am moved via Blendecques, Wizemws, Hallines, Setques, Lumbres, Acquin-Westbecour, Bouvelinghem, Hailottes, Alquines, waied an hour at Bouvelinghem for quide did not turn up so moved without them. Went long way round. Billeted in Alquines, real good billet, clean & large, very nice people.
Entry.74: Rained all day, outpost scheme postponed, went for a route march in the wet. Only Battn out. Got very wet.
Entry.75: Still raining, no parades, gave pt lectures on outpost, feet inspection.
Entry.76: Still raining, stopped in billet all day.
Entry.77: Cleared up a bit in the afternoon so went for a route march via Journy.
Entry.78: Started delayed scheme, 19th Battn did attack passing trough outposts went off very well loss of direction. Chappie & Buck came to dinner. Cablegram from Mum. Birthday wishes.
Entry.79: Same attacks as yesterday no direction lost this time.
Entry.80: Left Alquines at 8.0 am taking same course as before arrived at Arques about 6.30 pm. Had row with colonel on way over the band not playing for A Coy of 17 Battn attached.
Entry.81: No drill today had kit inspection. Telegram from Te.
Entry.82: On court martial in morning, carried out manoeuvres in Bois de Clairmarais.
Entry.83: Birthday parcel from mother arrived today. Had Chappie & Buch & Cpl Harbeck to dinner, & night menu fowl etc sgts of both B & D companies sent me congratulations.
Entry.84: Swimming carnival in afternoon went off well despite the rain showers.
Entry.85: Sunday Church parade in morning went to communion.
Entry.86: More manoeuvres in the woods excellent training sent all sections separately on a bearing, 12 out of 14 arrived at right spot. Aiming in the training at developing the initiative of the section A.C.O. He will want it in the next stunt.
Entry.87: Company went digging trenches at the Chateau de Batavia. I went to a cooking demonstration at Hazebrouch. Rather a good show had dinner with Anderson.
Entry.88: Coy went to the baths in the morning. Rode to St Omer in the afternoon, found cricket wicket on which to finish competition, the four Battalion teams are playing off.
Entry.90: Batt played 20th today & were beaten by a innings, wicket very wet, scores small. Training at Chateau.
Entry.91:
Fine day, played 18th won by 30 runs, this leaves us to play the 20th for the final.

18/7/17

Coy went out to do a line bombing stunt for the education of the Div commander, went off very well, 2 slight casualties. Some of the men rather scared, not much initiative shown by majority of men played.

20th Batt criket lost by 30 runs.
Entry.92: Church parade in the morning, went for a walk in the afternoon to 17th Battn on the other side of the wood, arranged for a football match on Thursday.
Entry.93: Went for a route march Arques, Blendecques, Le Bibison, Hurringhem, Wardsecquis, Campagne to Arques. After vaccinated fell out sick.
Entry.94: Close order drill in the wood, did staff ride in afternoon. Wrote Coy orders on advanced guard scheme. Orders collected by Brigadier will return them when criticised. Wrote to Mum.
Entry.95: Wednesday ½ Holiday. Gave Lecture in the morning, spent afternoon in writing & having a good scrub down.
Entry.96:
Orders returned. Mine was the only one which was any

good. The other Coy commanders had to go & do another. Weather fine. Left Billets early, men reviewed by General Birdwood. March by on the canal bank, marching not as good as might have been, rained in the afternoon.
Entry.97: Sat on a court martial all the afternoon. Case of stealing boots in St Omer, very monotonous case. One man tried to prove an alibi, lied very well but not well enough.
Entry.98: Drill in morning, bomb throwing & grenade shooting in the afternoon. Some very good shooting registered.
Entry.99: Sunday wrote & carved pipe, sat on a Board of inquiry on Bain, Timmings & 2 M.M.P., not finished.
Entry.100:
Practice parade for Sir D. Haig inspection on 29th. Div parade excellent performance. In afternoon went to a lecture on m. guns at Hazebrouch. Travers was in bus coming back.

He talks & acts like a large headed boy which no doubt he is.
Entry.101: Board of Inquiry in morning. Rained most of day spent in cleaning up for to-morrows parade.
Entry.102: Review went off very well. Haig expressed satisfaction etc at the way men turned out which was really fine.
Entry.103: Went to Chateau in morning shooting & bombing, court of Inquiry in the afternoon. Col went on leave to England.
Entry.104: Training at Batavia again showery but got in some good work, spoke to Gen Smythe Div Commander for ¼ hr on different subjects. Court of Inquiry again re Bain etc.
Entry.105: Inquiry in morning to get further evidence in regard to finding. Had afternoon off with intention of doing a night stunt, rained stunt off, payed men.
Entry.106: Sunday took L Gunners to Chateau to do some shooting.
Entry.107: Went out to the wood new formation for attack practiced to cope with German new method of defence which is a system distributed in depth, series of shell holes in front (fortified) then holes joined together & still further back consolidated lines. Ample supply of reserves for counter attacks at night, 4 pm went to a lecture given by the Captain now a Major who gave the lecture while I was at the 2nd Army school Wisques last September, also one at 8 pm by Col Bridges in the Hotel de Ville, Arques on wood lighting rather boring bit of an old woman.
Entry.108: Route march round wood then into St Omer & back along the Canal. Reviewed by the Brig on way back.
Entry.109:
Another route march St Omer round wood back

intercompany competition on way back to see which company is to represent Battalion in the Bge Competition. Conditions are 1 coy per Battn judged in organisation, marching, drill, rifle exercise & turnout. D Coy won easy, the march past in column of fours was the finest I had ever seen.
Entry.110: Divisional stunt attacking wood, 3 Bge leap frog, great sport going through wood men catching rabbits, pheasants, no luck with the deer though. Stunt went off well no direction lost though the wood was very thick. Lillie joined up & was put to D company, I was not altogether overjoyed.
Entry.111: Put in the day practicing for the competition, men drilled & marched exceedingly well.
Entry.112: Received orders at 11.30 pm last night that competition was to take place to-morrow at 9.30 am, very rushed & result was that company did not turn out as well as they might have. The 17th won then 20th, 18 & 19th last, rather a bunk. We got 1st place in rifle exercises but came down in turn out, organisation not perfect, lost marks there too. I did not pay enough attention to details of organisation & turnout.
Entry.113:
Sunday. Went to Harbeck & had tooth stopped last filled in St Omer last October. In afternoon went on a ride to Aire with Bennettvia the canal then to Boeseghem went into estaminet de la rose blanche. I saw the 2 girls, remembered me after 18 months. Asked after Sherbon, Dent & John Blumer. Came back through Boeseghaem

Renescure.

10/9/17

Saw plans for next attack. Took company over ground which was marked out the represent ground of actual attack, no much good as you had to imagine the contours etc, was in command of Battn all day. Boydon gone on leave to England. I shall be 2nd in Command of Battn for the attack.

Went to a University dinner at
Entry.114: Bge H.Q. Renescure very good, among others there were present Smythe, M.G. Div Commander, General Wisdom, Sir Alex McCormack, Col Pyke, Ralyston, Murphy, Chappie, Buck, Roly Dowling, Len Robson. Some good speeches sang Varisty Songs.
Entry.115:
Left Billets at 3.30 am to carry out attack at dawn

over ground. Col in command got roared on by Brigadier.
Entry.116: On the move left Billets 8.0 am marched to billets just outside Steenvorde practically same as last October, via Le Nieppe, Staple, Horndehem, St Sylvestre Chappel, fine cold day good for marching.
Entry.117: Acting as 2nd in command to Battn, left billets 6.30 am marched to Dickebusch via Abide, Reninghelst, Ouderdom, good marching day only a few fell out. Obtained enough bivowacks & tents for men to sleep.
Entry.118: Fine day, walked to Ouderdom to see a miniature of the ground for the attack, excellently done, gives one a very good idea of contours, etc.
Entry.119:
Storkey & company commander went up to the line at 2.30 am, his battalion will be moving up on the night 17-18th & will not take part in the hop over. Fleet of 14 German

machines came over dropped a few bombs on transport lines in the vicinity getting a few horses & men, 27 horses 11 men. 

John Gray wounded slight.
Entry.120: Fritz shelling back areas very consistently with one long rang gun about 6" calibre. Visited by a another fleet about mid-day. 2 large Gotha planes among them dropped no bombs. No planes hit by our guns on either occasion.
Entry.121:
Batt moved out today. C & D Coy to Ypres, A & B to Bellevard Farm & ridge respectively. I was left behind at transport lines not very me being left behind. Hope they do well Efiller one of the men I had tried to reform went back on me at the eleventh hour & deserted this morning, rather disappointing for me. Foster returned today & is with me at T. line, sent photo of fooicers group & Percy Jones home.

I have again sent in again for a decoration I wonder what will happen to decorations this time. Booth gave me some addresses to write to I fancy he had an idea he will be killed. Hope not, he is one of the best officers we have. Bennett will be alright. Doubtful about Storky & Lillie.
Entry.122:
Quiet day. Artillery fairly active. At night A & B Cot took over front line B Coy in posts, A on Westhock ridge D Coy on Bellewarde Ridge & C on Bellewarde Pn. great activity during night getting up ammunition etc. Arthur Cocks wounded last night.

19/9/17

Cloudy. Hope it does not rain. Aeroplanes all over the place, attack to take place to-morrow morning. All battalion to be in place by 3.30 am. Scotch on left, 7 Bge on right. 1st Div the Tommies & then South Africans 16 ml front. 

20/9/17

Cloudy but not raining. Artillery started at 4.30 am intense barrage. Have 9.2" How just behind front line to fire after advance. 1st news 1 & 2 objectives taken by 10.0 am. 17th beateb back reinforced by 18th took Anzac Home & 3rd objective. Casualties up yo noon for Bge 300 very slight indeed. Nielson, Segal, Sill, Armint wounded, few men killed, not many. Chappie is in charge of dressing station on Bellewarde ridge. Col of Field Ambulance killed. All other batt took objectives as far as known, good number of prisoners look frightened & tired. Browning joined up & went to front with Belcher.
Entry.123:
Weather still fine, went for a walk up to dressing stn on Menin Rd. Had look over Ypres with Forster, very much knocked about. The new front has settled

down, whole attack successful except for the South Africans who were very badly knocked about. Fritz attached along whole front last night but was everywhere repulsed 17, 18 & 20th Battn were relieved to-night, 19th staying in attached to
Entry.124: Bge. Casualties up to date in Bttn. Lichner killed & 15 O.R. wounded, 6 officers & 59 .R. Bge casualties about 500.
Entry.125: Weather still fine. Battn relieved to-night by
Entry.126: Div 52nd Batt. Coy had only 1 killed 13 wounded. Starkey has done well also Lillie, Sgt Huxley did very ggod work & Cpl Hutchinson, have recommended him for a Commission. Batt casualties, killed 1 off, 27 O.R. wounded 8 off 91 O.R. Walker Johnson came through alright. Met the Battn with guide gave them a good meal all in by 12.0 midnight.
Entry.127:
Left transport line & went to Halifax Camp near Ouderdom,

spent part of the night in playing poker though I never gambled in principle the playing for small stakes makes the game fascinating & a man shows his character plainer here than anywhere else, I found it quite interesting watching the faces & manners of those playing. It also teaches self control.
Entry.128: Left Halifax camp 8.0 am & marched via Ouderdom, Reninghelst, to Wiffenhock where all are encamped in tents forming a square with fruit trees all round, the square is of grass & looks very well, still acting 2nd in command.
Entry.129:
Beautiful weather, roll call & inspection. Joined men from reinforcement camp. Boyden & Douglas back.

26/9/17

4 & 5th Divs had a stunt this morning over 6 mls front entirely successful,
Entry.130:
Div badly knocked about. Tomebeck taken and

all of Polygon wood now in our hands.
Entry.131: Spent day in drilling, weather holds good. Enemy aeroplanes come here at night dropped large no of bombs on Poperinghe.
Entry.132:
Went for a route march in morning. Read still away on stretcher bearer party, left on night before of the stunt 26/9/17.

Band plays in square every evening, very pleasant.
Entry.133: Drilled in morning, route march in afternoon. Bill Langham arrived back from school.
Entry.135: Storkey & myself went to baths instead, spent afternoon in writing letters.
Entry.136: Left camp 8.0 am marched to camp near Oududoun via Reninghelst . Reid arrived back, 6 casualties.
Entry.137:
Left camp 8.15 am, marched to the Belgian chateau near Ypres, men billeted in dug outs, visited line with Bennett and

Langham, quite a good day, very little hostile shelling.
Entry.138: Did practically nothing all day, received orders to be ready to move in support of attacking Battalion.
Entry.139: Left camp at 2.0 am, moved to Railway wood, next to Roulen railway just outside Ypres, by zero hour 6.0 am. At zero + 2 hrs moved to Westhock ridge & two hours later on to Anzac Spur, here we dug in shortly afterwards, we moved nearer railway to St Josephs Institute & dug in again, not so much shelling here. Night was very cold & wet. The dug out we had made leaked like a sieve. Col C.R.A. Pye killed, wound in head.
Entry.140: Showery all day. 18 pr are moving up to position just in our rear. Sent Lieut Bennett up to front line to take over. Major Becks arrived & took over Battalion. Moved up at night & took over from 7 Bge, attack a complete success.
Entry.141: From midnight until daybreak worked on the trench to make a continuous line. Succeeded pretty well just of daylight. Fine day rather pleasant in trench very little shelling.
Entry.142: Large number of enemy planes over early in the morning. Shelled fairly heavily in the morning & again in the afternoon. At dusk he began blowing us out with 5.9" Howitzer shells, cleaned out about 50 yds of the line. Attacked on left & right not successful but lost about 20 men, blew in my H.Q. buried mess gear etc.
Entry.143: Shelled out of New H.Q. this morning. Company was relieved by groups during morning & afternoon. 23rd Batt relieved us & relief went back to support lines. Had lively night looking for H.Q. in the dark, raining very heavily, attack to take place in the morning. All Bges very weak.
Entry.144: Showery in early morning, at two moved to support line behind
Entry.145:
Battn. 17th Battn & 20th doing attack. In these lines we were subjected to very heavy shelling. Lost here Lt Bennett killed & Lillie wounded. Lt Langham had been evacuated day before with rheumatism. At 11.0 am I received a message from Battn to go & reinforce the right flank of the 17th Battn which had failed to get its objective. On arriving at an old German trench well forward I could not see any line in front & was told by men in the trench that they were the farthest advanced. As I did not think this was correct I sent out a patrol & closely followed it with one platoon. On reaching Dairy wood the sniping from left & right flank became very severe especially that from the direction of Daisy wood which was in the 6th Bge sector. From here I sent back a message for the

remainder of the Company. The patrol here reported that front line was some 6-700 yds ahead & held a mixture of 17, 18, 10 & 21 Byn but with nobody on the right or left. When more men arrived under Lt Blake I spread them out along the edge of the wood & engaged the enemy both in Dairy wood & in a strong point about D23 d57. We then proceeded to search Dairy wood & moved through it to the northern edge taking a Hun gun on the way through. From the edge I saw one or 2 Huns leave their trench & run back through the wood. I immediately gathered the nearest men & moved across the open ground in front of Daisy wood. Moving from shell hole to hole & shooting at every available target we reached the trench & the occupants surrendered. Our party consisted of Lt Smyth, 10 O.R. & myself. Lt R.A.W. Smith & 20 O.R. were

 Cpl Lynch Patrol.

wounded on the way up. The prisoners totalled 15 & at least 10 others were hit while trying to get away. Our advance was covered by the fire from a L.G. under Sgt Birtles firing from the Eastern corner of Dairy wood. The gun did excellent shooting. On being reinforced by more men the party under Sgt O’Hara moved through the wood & took up a position of posts at the edge without further opposition although the sniping was very severe all the time. A line consisting of posts was then formed with the rest of the men going up Dairy wood & the right flank of the Batt in the front line.

At 12 O clock that night the posts on my right had also been relieved, but this afterwards proved to be incorrect. I put Blake in charge of the Dairy wood posts and

Lt Bignell with A Coy filled in the gap on the left flank.

10/10/17

After being relieved I moved back to H.Q. along railway line, slept there until the afternoon & then moved back to Transport lines. Where the larger part of the Batt had arrived. Slept the sleep of the just that night.
Entry.146: Battn billeted in Ypres so moved up there, slept the night. Had another good night sleep, was complemented by both Major Briers & the General on the work I had done. This time I think it means a sure decoration or it ought to.
Entry.147:
Left Ypres by train at 8.0 am should have left by 6.20 am, train late, disembarked at Abele marched to Steenvoorde, billeted in farm houses on other side of Town. Percy Jones & Belcher rejoined, Percy looks very well. Casualties in stunt 9 officers 100 O.R. in D Coy, 2 off 48 O.R. lost, killed,

Lieut Bennett, H.E. Smith wounded, Foster, Lillie, Dr Morgan, Bartle, Roy Smith, Ross. I had some wonderful escapes again. Major Bevis now Colonel.
Entry.148: Rained practically all day. Had kit inspection & roll call, payed men double & f5 for presents. Reported Roy Smith died.
Entry.149: Sunday went to church parade in the morning, Communion afterwards. Went for ride with Col Bevis to Mont de Kats in the afternoon, a beautiful view from the monastery . Talked about various officers, Major Middleton will very likely return as 2nd in command. Boyden not being made rather hard lines on me.
Entry.150: Commenced parades, have Langham & Read as officers, Jones was to go to A Coy, told but fine talk about going into the line again. Not too keen on it myself just yet.
Entry.151: Received orders to be ready to move by 10 am proceeding to Belgian Battery corner to do work on light railways. Boarded busses at 10.30 & proceeded via Abele, outskirts of Poperinghe, Valeringht , Ypres to X rds, 1 ml from battery corner, waited there until found the camp & then marches to camp. Huts good & dry. Band came up with us.
Entry.152: Commenced work Batt supplied 500 men working in parties of 100 on new work & reballasting old portions. Capt Boyden in charge of party.
Entry.153: I am in charge of party to-day 400 men worked on line up as far as Menin gate. Fine day rather cold.
Entry.154: Party out again. Boyden in charge. Rained very heavily in afternoon. Except the moving back, a day or two now. Canadians take over this part of the line.
Entry.155:
Parties work again today. I am in charge, fine day, spent time in roaming over Ypres. Took photo of the ramparts. On top of Rampart is an enormous brass bell probably used before the advance as a gas alarm, returned at 4.30 pm. Storkey has reached England. All of them are in Wandsworth. 

21/10/17

Capt Cullen in charge of party doing same kind of work.
 Sunday. Enemy planes very active at night. Manston & Fitzroy arrived. Fine day went for a ride with Cullen to Poperinghe. Had afternoon tea saw Major Kirkwood. Has an M.C., & since I last saw him. Hun planes again very active.

22/10/17

Cullen took post, rained fair part of the day. Hun planes again dropped bombs late. Hundreds of our planes up in the afternoon. French attacked & took Houthulst wood north of Passchendaele. Both 1st & 2nd Divisions are moving up

again.
Entry.157: up to the line, we may be left on this work. Canadians will attack shortly. Passchendaele has to be taken at all costs before the winter sets in.
Entry.158: Boyden has the party. Raining. Stopped in camp all day.
Entry.159: McKeekin took party, raining. Wrote letters home & sent Xmas to Te, Mabel, Mabel Wallace, Mum, Dorothy. Fritz bombs pretty well every night, full moon coming on again. Drs Wallack, Robertson & Plummer returned.
Entry.160: My turn again, spent day in roaming round all the parties. Cool, sunny day. Had rather enjoyable time.
Entry.161: Bill Cullen with party to-day. Very easy time for Coy Commanders, we have the responsibility in the line.
Entry.162:
Another quiet day, our bombing raids have started

 

large of our planes went over to-night, dropped 18 tons of bombs. 1 Fritz came over early, dropped 4 bombs 1 got 12 killed 47 wounded of 2nd Battalion then others got Pioneer & Tommies, large haul.
Entry.163: Fine day, planes all over the place, large planes of ours went over again, moving to-morrow to a camp near by, will do front line after all.
Entry.164: Moved to new camp near Cape Belge. Huts but very muddy. Read & 2 N.C.O. went up to support Battn position, front quiet. Went for a walk with Robinson to Div canteen, saw Peden & Langham. Huns very active at night.
Entry.165: Robinson & 2 N.C.O.’s visited line. Rained most of the day. Fair amount of shelling in forward areas using great quantities of gas shells, casualties among forward Battalion.
Entry.166:
Beautiful day, a couple of Hun planes very high up. 1st American plane similar to ours but have a star on body. Jones, Satchell & Col went up to line. Very often feel as if I would like someone to think of more than the home people. Don’t think I would advise anyone to do as I did before I came away. It leaves a space very hard to fill.

The Colonel told me that I had got the M.C. very nice to have a bit of colour up after 2 years service. I was rather hurt when Majorie spoke about the prize for general proficiency.
Entry.167: Fine but misty. Visited Westhoek to see frontier. I am going to take up good accommodation. Dug out to take 12 for H.Q. Shelled Westhoek ridge heavily all the while, got back by 1.0 pm safe enough.
Entry.168: Fine day, left camp 10.0 am, moved to Westhoek ridge arrived about 2 pm. Shelling a bit when we arrived, we have a good dug out & men shelters rain proof, dug-out holds 7 officers (C & D Coy) & 6 batmen. Rec letter from General Birdwood on gaining M.C.
Entry.169: Few shells during day & very few fatigues quite a home.
Entry.170: Shelled ridge constantly all day with one battery of 4.2" guns shooting from about Becelacre on a T.B. 95° had 2 casualties, Macneilly & Lt-------. Lt Bartle has died.
Entry.171:
Misty but cleared towards midday, planes brought down by a Fritz hit volplaned & seemed to land safely, moved up 4 pm to support position A & B Coy in front line

shelling ridge very heavily as we left relieved 18 Batt by 5.30 without casualties. McKeech took patrol of 20 O.R. & L.G. out every night, went forward a good 1000 yds.
Entry.172: Canadians attacked at 6 am everything went off well, good day start though rained a bit at midday, probably hindered Fritz more than us. Took Passchendale, Hun reported to be destroying machinery as far back as Liege perhaps in preparation for another retreat. S.O.S. at dusk on Canadian front, no attack developed.
Entry.173: Relieved today by 24 Batn, rather a surprise, moved back to camp by Lille road, no casualties on way out though anxious time, got into camp by 12 midnight.
Entry.174:
Moved at 9.30 am to Pioneer corner where embussed for Steenvoorde arrived there at 4.0 pm, good trip,

spirit of officers fine, full of fun, rough houses all the way. Billeted with C Coy no officers billet for D.
Entry.175: Fine day, went with Col to Bge. Have been given job of starting & organising sports in the Batn & to represent Btn on Bge committee. Football, Hockey & cross country runs to be for Bge competition, tho a day devoted to drill, rest to games, got billet in an estaminet for the remainder of stay here. 4 pm in the one room officers now are Lt Robinson, 2/Lt reech & 2/Lt Read.
Entry.176: Rained nearly all day, no parades. Had kit inspection. Had meeting of Bge committee for sports, drew up programme, probable trip to England for Bge team Officers. Spoken to by the Col at night, must get up enthusiasm otherwise show will fail.
Entry.177: Reveille at 5 am, Battn ready to move at 7.30 am. 2nd in command for the march everything O.K. & to time, moved via Steenvoode, St Sylvestre-Cappel, Kooten loop & billeted just outside Long Croix, not very far from Staple where we visited when on our way to the Somme last July 12 months ago. Men’s billets good our billet one small room has to hold four of us.
Entry.178: Went into St Omen to but sporting material with Redgrave of 18th Btn. Had good day, saw Col on return & fixed up programme for sports, men taking very well to sports & games.
Entry.179: Had match bet. A & D Coy. A won by 12 – 3. Good game, should get a very good Btn team. Letter from Alice Fisher, Perryman. Capt Atkinson & all officers & detail from reinforcement arrived here tonight.
Entry.180: Had another game with A Coy, played myself, at ½ time we were leading by 9 – 3 but at the finish the game ended in favour of A Coy by 19 – 9, went down to B Coy. At night picked 2 teams to represent the Battalion. Have 2 new officers one in B & other in C.
Entry.181: Went for route march to Oxclave, Cassel & then back to Billets. Football teams remained behind to practice for match.
Entry.182: The two Batt teams had a game, very fast & a good game right through. I had to go to court martial at Wallon Cappel, 18th Btn H.Q. so missed it. Had dinner with A Coy. John Grey & Dos were there. Robbie & Reech go very merry afterwards, a good night.
Entry.183:
A Coy played B won 8 – 6, D played C lost 8 – 0, both

excellent game played myself in the latter match, so stiff next day could hardly get on my horse.
Entry.184: Reveille at 5.0 am, left billet at 8.30 am, marched via Les Ciseaux, L’Hoffland, Borre, Pradelles, Strazelle, outside Merris to Meteren. Coy was billeted near Bailleul. People of farm gave us jugged hare, etc, we are the 1st Aust to be billeted here.
Entry.185:
Left again at 8.0 am, marched via Nooteboom, Le Verguier, Steenwerck, to Le Hollebeque farm near Jesus farm of olden days, walked into Erquinghem with Jones & McMeekin, an afternoon place is exactly the same no more knocked about. Some of people recognised us immediately as the Division & welcomed up. These people seem to know

as much if not more of our doings than we ourselves. Billeted in Huts, plenty of room & quite comfortable.
Entry.186: Not so much football as in the previous billets. Went with Col & other Coy commanders to look over position we would have to take up if Armentieres was attacked. Visited Armentieres & Houplines. Doohan got me a piece of china from Houplines. Returned with Col via L’Armie, streaky Bacon farm a bit more knocked about not much. Madelene & Germaine have gone. Also people on Bois Grerner has gone otherwise farming going on as usual.
Entry.187: Drilled during day, ground very wet so work resolves itself into route march & physical drill.
Entry.188:
Drill again, had a meeting at Bge to fix up match.

First match on 26th against 17th Battn. 20th via M. Guns went to show at nigh given by a troop the 5.7’s very good indeed. Mess fixed up today, no president elected waiting for Major Middleton to come back, Keech & Hayes are running mess.
Entry.189: Route marches again. Formed raiding platoon, comprised of 18C & 18D Coy men, Sgt Cock & Huxley, Cpl Kirkup & Goudy are N.C.O.’s should give a very good account of themselves, Major Middleton came back. Had first dinner in the mess, very good one indeed. Credit to men .
Entry.190: Raiding platoon in working order. Inspection by C.O., men looked very well. Rode over to 20th Battn to get ground for Coy. match. A played C, ended in a draw, no scores.
Entry.191: Cold day. Heavy wind. Sunday service in YMCA tent. Rode into Steenwerck to Hockey meeting, stick took, will mile play 18 Battn next Sunday. Saw Bean at night gave him an account of 9 November stint.
Entry.192:
Drill in morning. Football match between 17 & 19 in Steenwerck in afternoon, we won by 17 to 3, should win the Bge competition easily.

27/11/17

Played the 26 Battery 3rd Div this afternoon lost by 20 – nil, played with our second team, must get a match on with our
Entry.194: Fine day ½ holiday, on range this morning, ride into Baillieu this afternoon. Had good ride, afternoon tea in town, saw Major Dunlop & Capt Fauar on the way in.
Entry.195:
Battn marched to Bailleul training ground, did an

 

attack over a small sector & then returned back to camp, cold day good for marching, went into Steenwerck.
Entry.196: Left camp this morning at 7.30 pm with 3 other Coy Commanders, Capr Cullen, Atkinson & McMeckin, to go & see over sector of line we are to take over. Rode through Nieppe, Le Rossignal, Ploegsteert to Touquet Berthe where we left the horses then struck across country to Lancashire Support Div took trench to the convent, 36th Btn H.Q. went with C.O. to Vampire Support line some 500 yds behind front line. Had a good look around, similar in every respect to Bois Grenier of last year. Seems to be a very quiet front.
Entry.197:
Drill in the morning. Battn team played the M.G.C. football in afternoon resulted in a draw, 3 all, good fast game, don’t think umpire knew too much of the game, our men got

over the line 3 times in the last 10 minutes one of which was a try, the umpire gave a 5 scrum each time.
Entry.198: Sunday. Church parade in Cinema Hall, Steenwerck, spent afternoon looking over company for inspection tomorrow, at least ¾ of Coy remained in billets polishing up.
Entry.199: Parade in morning, C.O. inspection, men looked well. 13 pl picked as best platoon, will represent Cot in Btn competition for next Saturday. Left with Bill Cullen for Paris at 10 am, took train at Steenwerck arrived at Boulogne at 5.0 pm, stayed night at Hotel de Paris.
Entry.200: Walked round town in morning took 2.10 train for Paris met Doc & Sgt Vance aboard bound for the same place, arrived at 8.30 pm went by Tube to Hotel St Petersburg, looks good, had tea & went to bed.
Entry.201: Slept well, breakfast at 9.30 am went for a walk, reported at Place St Honoré near Place de Verdôme, did some shopping & then had dinner at Hotel, in afternoon walked up Les Champ d’Elycée to Arc de Triomphe & back to Rue Cumartin to Hotel. Went with Doc Porter, Cullen, Vance & 2 21st Btn men to the Restaurant for dinner & then to the Follies Bergère. Arrived about ½ way through spent time in walking round classing Tabbies, got Hotel at 11.35 pm, a real good night.
Entry.202:
In the morning visited the exposition of war pictures in Les Tuileries, some excellent photographs, dinner at Hotel then went to paymaster near St Lazare station then drove round the Place de Concorde, Pont Alex lll. Eiffel Tower, Grand Rue Trocadero, Bois de Boulogne.

Had afternoon tea at the Chatan, drink at American Bar near Madeline & the Hotel for dinner, went to Grand Opera House at 7.20 pm, saw Thaïs very fine indeed both in singing & ballet.
Entry.203: Saw paymaster again today. Had dinner at night at Maxims. The Doc birthday so had some dinner cost about 140 Fr, ½ way through had a fancy for some snails so helped our party from Frenchmans plate he went very crook. After dinner went to the Florence Hotel in taxi with an American. Arrived back about 12.
Entry.204: Dull day but took car to Versailles, fine car, made good pace all the way, saw over the Palace & grounds, arrived back at 5.30 pm had tea & went to Samson et Dalila , bit heavy, saw fine ballet after play.
Entry.205: Walked round town during day, went into Pathé Frires home, photographs fitted to telephone receivers, sit at a desk, put the required no. of the disc & place receiver on ears. At night went to Opera Comique & saw Carmen some very fine voices.
Entry.206: Had photos taken, 3 photos combined, went to Bastille, had dinner at Pruniers ( ) afterwards went to Sacré Coêur, were shown all over it. Has enormous foundation & was started 50 yrs before the war, not yet finished. Most beautiful church I have ever seen. All mosaic work in marble. Had afternoon tea at the “Liddy" in Caumartin St, very flash almost overwhelmed by perfumes. Had dinner at Ciro cost 86 Fr for 3. Then went to Alhambra near Place de la Republique.
Entry.207: Went round low quarter from Republique to St Germain, on the ramparts. Had drink at American Bat, took 2 friends to Afternoon Tea. Bill & I dined at Pruniers, went to Alhambra Theatre, met 2 friends, very nice. Caught 11.20 train to Calais arrived there 12.20 pm.
Entry.208: Stayed in Calais about 1½ hr, reached Hazebrouck 2.20 pm caught another train to Steenwerck arrived there 4.30 pm very slow & cold, walked out to camp.
Entry.209:
Parades. Storkey has arrived back 2nd in command of D Coy. Robinson very sore. Storkey transferred to B Coy. C Coy won platoon competition then B, D & A last, drill not good in any of them, turn out good.

Rode to Neuve Eglise with Blake to have M.C. awarded by General Birdwood.
Entry.210: Left Camp 9.00 am & marched to Le Rossignol camp via Waterlands Camp & Nieppe, about 3 mls march, plenty of room. Officer quarters also good. Coy messes again but have a recreation hut. Bad headache tonight.
Entry.211: Went up the line with Fisher, saw Mac & Bill Cullen. Have good quarters & very comfortable. Football match in the afternoon. A Coy raiders against D Coy, lost 9 – 0.
Entry.212: Sunday. Cold day. Church in Y.M.C.A. Had communion. Match in afternoon very funny lost to C Coy by 13 – 10. Bill Langham gone to Bge as gum boot officer for winter. Keech went with raiding pt to Bge for training. Percy Jones evacuated with poisoned foot. Wrote to Mr Haywood (Percy’s friend) Dad, Min Elliot, Bank. Ham piano in recreation hut, Bartin pianist.
Entry.213: Cold but fine, frozen hand. Had parade for few minutes in morning them did work inside hut. Aeroplane flight 2 – 4 Hun.
Entry.214: Still frozen, beautiful day, route march in morning to Neuve Eglise & back, physical jerks in the afternoon, wrote to Dorothy & Marjorie.
Entry.215: Spent morning in getting ready to move. Left camp at 2.0 pm moved to Lancashire Support farm, relieved B Coy. Relief complete by 3.30 pm. Fatigues parties left at 4.30 pm, 65 men on every night from company & 10 in day time. Have dug-out in farm, 3 bunks & stove.
Entry.216:
Saw Colonel in the morning, very heavy fog, branches & grass are laden with frozen fog & every thing is white, same as Prainneville of last year in December. In afternoon went to front line with Bastin & N.C.O.s, had good look round.

Went across gap on left to Post of 7 Bge. Fritz saw us & threw over a few pineapple bombs, no damage done, few gas shells at night.
Entry.217: Still foggy & frozen hard. Saw Cadle of 18th in the morning. He has had about a year in England. Charlie Read came up in afternoon with Sgt Marshall & Cock, going out on patrol at midnight.
Entry.218: Charlie Read came back about 4.0 am, lay down for a sleep. About 9. am a few shells came over, he went outside to see where they were falling & was killed by a piece in the head. We buried him in the Cemetery near Le Touquet Birthe. Padre buried him, his brother & myself were present. Location Sheet 28 S.W. U 26 b 55.15. Moved H.Q. into dug-out with C Coy.
Entry.219: Rather quite day, very foggy. H.Q. a bit cramped but feel much safer.
Entry.220: Rec orders to relieve D Coy 18th Battn, Capt Lowther in front line moved up at 3.30 pm, relief complete by 6.0 pm. C.T. very shallow also front line, fair amt of shelling & bombing with L.T. Mortars – pineapples – otherwise quite alright.
Entry.221: Col. Payed a visit in the early morning, quite all day, went down to Battn H.Q. in afternoon & Trennery told me there was a parcel for me at Q.M. Store, sent man down to get it. It was from Mrs Harwood & weighed almost 58 lbs contents were, Tinned turkey, fowel, Ham, pudding, beefsteak pie, Yorkshire pudding, French beans, asparagus, pork chops, sausages, crystallised fruits, biscuits, butter, cheese, cream, 2 bottles of Port. Wrote home.
Entry.222: Had our Xmas dinner today. Brought up Kilpatrick & Bas from front line, went real well, not putting out enough wire, full moon & is very clear practically impossible to do any work outside front line.
Entry.223: Visited front line early, took bearings on to positions of trench mortars, batteries etc that had been picked up during the night, a battery of 4.2", & signalling station, put out at night 87 coils of wire started work at 10.0 pm.
Entry.224: Visited front line in morning at stand to, very quite clear but very cold wind blowing, stopped in dug-out most of day, relieved by B Coy, moved back to Lancashire Support farm.
Entry.225:
Salvaged a stove from Ploegsteert wood, installed in the hut, makes things very comfortable, fatigues

to front line & support line not very strenuous though.
Entry.226: Frozen, very cold, spent most of day in roaming round. Major Walker gone as town Major somewhere.
Entry.227: Still cold, very quite all day. Visited H.Q. Had Mothers photo painted by a man Dixon in Pioneers.
Entry.228: Made arrangements for a dinner tonight at Le Rossignol 8.30 pm. Menus painted by Dixon. Relieved by 18th Battn 5.0 pm, reached acmp at 7.0 pm saw menus very good, dinner at 9.30 pm success rather a surprise to everybody. Cost about 100 Fr each for D Coy.
Entry.229: Cold day no parade, had kit inspection. Atkinson went from front line suffering from gas.
Entry.230:
Men had baths at Pont Neippe, went with Kennedy to Bailleul, saw his brother at Corps gas school. Had dinner

at Club then went to No 1 C.C.S. saw Percy Jones, spent afternoon & night with the Nurses. Had very nice dinner indeed, reached camp again by 12.o midnight.
Entry.231: Moved camp to Tugusoll camp, good camp clean & comfortable.
Entry.232: Moved to Laurence Fm, relieved B Coy, night quite C & D Coy together.
Entry.233: Quite day hardly a shot fired, fatigues in the morning & night, took photo of Charlie Read’s grave also of Jackson.
Entry.234: Another quite day A & B Coy gave a dinner. Col did some card tricks. Mac go blotto as usual.
Entry.235:
Bill Cullen, Mac & Hunter Kirke paid us a visit today. Bill’s photo has arrived from Paris, not mine. Fired a few shots at a 6th Bge working party. Snowed practically all

day, played Poker 170 frcs.
Entry.236: Clear day. Fritz shooting again at 6th Bge in morning, these parties bit of a nuisance, relieved B Coy 18th Capt O’Donnell in front line, A Coy on right.
Entry.237: Visited front line took lots of bearings. Lot of pineapples coming over all day, also some minnies. Snowing.
Entry.238: Thawed today leaving everything very soft & wet, lot of minnies thrown over on front line by 21 post. Robbie is in front line so have to do all the intelligence myself. Keeps me pretty busy.
Entry.239: Visited Bill Cullen this morning, had breakfast with him, good day very little shooting & very quite night. Allan came back in the afternoon.
Entry.240:
Frozen again this morning clear, lot of planes up both

Fritz & ours. Relieved B Coy complete by 6.15 pm. Moved back to Lancashire Farm. Allan wiring Himfire support.
Entry.241: Whole company out on fatigues at night, working men very hard. Rained at night. Allan on wiring party, finishing were in front of Himfire support towards 7th Bge.
Entry.242: Few fatigues during day, wiring again at night, finished. Rained most of day, very wet.
Entry.243:
Rained very heavily all day
 trenches & dug-outs flooded, lot of men looking for new homes. 
Allan on wiring could not find dump, very dark, no work done.
 Fisher on patrol.
Entry.244:
½ company out cleaning out the saps where they had fallen in 
remainder out at night doing some in front line.
 Relieved 18th Battn, moved back to Tugersoll camp.
Entry.245:
Cleaned up. Kit inspection & pay. Dad Boyden received his

Majority, rather a shock to me as Col Beiers had told me that in future promotions to higher rank would be made on alibility & not according to seniority. Foolishly I thought I would get something out of it, but it seems all men are alike, they cannot do want they think best because it is not usually done.
Entry.246: Saw Col in the morning about Boyden getting his majority, said that he had recommended me but was told by Bge that Boyden was to be given a trial. Went with Trennery & Arthur Cocks to I.C.C.S. to see Percy Jones, incidentally to see the Nurses. Saw Toly Hinds on the way to rejoin Battalion. Took nurses out for dinner to Bailleul. Major Walker is 2nd in command.
Entry.247:
Moved up to relieve B Coy in Laurence farm. Throwing some heavy stuff into Maison ’75 but got in without casualties.

Have H.Q.s in farm again. Allan, Hinds & myself together. Bastin in C Coy H.Q.s
Entry.248: Quiet day, rained a little, fatigue parties, as usual played Poker won 20 frcs. Bastin lost 182 frcs.
Entry.249: Warm & clear, played Poker again in the afternoon but lost 192 Frcs, usual fatigues.
Entry.250: Moved up & relieved D Coy 18th Battn in front line. M.G’s very active also minnies falling mostly near 21 – 21A posts. Makes craters 15 ft across. No casualties. Visited front line. Allan & Hinds in line, Baters with me.
Entry.251: Col. Came up early with Walker, went round line with them. Took bearings on to Minnie positions & a couple of gratinwerfgers.
Entry.252:
Visited line again, do it twice a day, got the artillery on to

the position of a couple of pineapple throwers with good results as they did not shoot again, did same to large minenwerfer & silenced it also.
Entry.253: Misty but quite warm again. Cleaned up line relieved by B Coy & moved back to Lancashire farm.
Entry.254: Fine day, fatigues all day, no parties at night. Visited by 3rd Div officer & B O.R. stayed night. – advance party to 3rd Div.
Entry.255: Foggy day, few of Hun aeroplanes over flying very low, dropped couple of bombs. Played poker again lost 142 frcs. Relieved at 8.30 pm marched back to Rortepyp, came near Neuve Eglise, arrived about 11.30 pm well before rest of the Battalion who came by Train from Ploegsteert.
Entry.256:
Trennery left early as billeting offices gone to Lumbres area. Had good clean up & clean clothes. Had ride in the

afternoon. Horses very fresh, should have some good rides at new billet. Officers in charge of platoons don’t take enough interest in their platoons, sent cables Home f30.
Entry.257: Had little drill in the morning, went for walk just before tea with Allan & Hutchinson C Coy to Ravelsburg. Ronald came & had dinner, met Molesworth, talks as much as ever – a genuine fool.
Entry.258: Cleaned up camp early in the morning left at 11.0 am marched to entraining place on other side of Neuve Eglise. Had dinner & entrained left ½ blankets behind & some of the men. Fussed another fool, arrived at Lumbres via Hazebrouck, Arques, at 5.00 pm, marched to Seninghem 5½ kilometres away where we billeted. Coy all together very compact & billets good. Have good room. Percy Jones arrived back.
Entry.259: Cold & misty, mist freezing & settling on grass etc. Coy went for a route match in morning, no parades in the afternoon.
Entry.260: Duty Company today, sent remainder of Coy on march without rifles, they enjoyed it, billets in good order.
Entry.261: Sunday. Went for a ride with Bill Cullen in the morning. Two company matches played in the afternoon B v C Coys & D v A, both scoreless games.
Entry.262:
Fatigue party sent to Musketry school Bayengham in the morning, remainder of Coy drilling. Played trial matches between 2 Battalion teams in afternoon, good game, hard to pick Battn team, finally picked – Fullback, Lt Trennery, Backs Adams, Butchart, Lt Kirke, Jones & Courtney. Forwards Graham, Lt Cooke, Dwyer

Tyrell, Sgt Ravell, Cleary, Thompson, Lt Plummer.
Entry.263: Route march through Coulomby, Verval, Quesques. Had dinner here splendid view could see Boulogne some 30 kilometres away, returned through Watterdal to billets. I am running the Sports again. Robinson left on leave for Paris. Allan piquet officer in St Omen.
Entry.264: Parade in the morning ½ holiday in afternoon should have played 18th Football but on account of rearrangement of Battalions did not come off.
Entry.265: Rained all day. Bill Cullen left on leave for England. Percy Jones in charge of company.
Entry.266:
Raining again today. All officers in company went to Pigeon School. I gave lecture to N.C.O’s & in afternoon took 6 of them out, marched on a plan

bearings. Went across country to Le Buisson near Alquines, returned at 5.15 pm, interesting I think to those who came.
Entry.267: Keech gave a demonstration in morning with his platoon, good display. Rifle exercises & P.T., football match against 18th in afternoon, very high wind blowing. 18th won by 3 – 0. Keen disappointment win as we thought after the 1st half that it was a sure thing.
Entry.268: Sunday again. Church parade in the morning on 18th Battn football ground. I was in charge of the parade. In afternoon rode over with Stockey & Percy Jones to No 1 N.Z. 3 Hosp at Wisques, stayed to Tea & went for walk afterwards, arrived back about 1.0 am.
Entry.269:
Parades all day. Had dinner at C. Coy at 6 pm, present – Trennery, Fred Lipscombe (came back yesterday), Fitzroy, Hunter Kube, Percy Jones, McDonald, Arthur Cooke & myself. Good dinner. Talk turned to the old subject about marrying English girls, none of them there were engaged or going to be.

12/2/18

Played 5th A.M.C. football in afternoon on
Entry.270: Army Musketry School ground near Lumbres won by 5 – 3.
Entry.271: Rained, no parades. 18th played T.M. Draw no scores. Everything musty & wet. Rec letters from Miss Hunt, Mother & Te. 2 photos of Te & Til’s baby. Te looks very well.
Entry.272: Wrote to Te await the reply with interest. Spent whole day in training for the platoon competition. Also in rapid loading & firing. Robinson returned from Paris.
Entry.273:
Whole company on range. Rode to Nielles in afternoon

to a lecture at Divisional H.Q. by General Wisdom who had been attached to 6th French Division for manoeuvres.
Entry.274: Cleaned equipment (washed) for G.O.C. inspection on 19th. Play T.M.B. draw 8 all, good, fast game.
Entry.275: Left Billets at 7.30 am, marched to range near Val-de-Lumbres, did musketry in morning everything went well. Had dinner on range at Bge. Les Blake helped. Bastin returned from school.
Entry.276: Holiday. Baths. Spent day in cleaning up for G.O.C. inspection. Rode into Lumbres with Keech in afternoon. Got my leave pass for England. Handed over all sports arrangements to Jones & Cooke.
Entry.277:
Inspected company early in the morning & then took

leave lorry to St Omer. Had dinner with Dick Allan & caught 1.0 pm train for Calais arrived at 3.0 no boat that afternoon. Had walk round town & stayed at Terminus Hotel. Met Capt who looks after messing arrangements at 2nd Army School, Wisques.
Entry.278: Left by 12 midday for Dover, took train & arrived in London 4.30 pm. Put up at Marble Arch Hotel. Had dinner at Jerymn Court, met Patterson & Allan, went with them to the Coliseum.
Entry.279: Spent the morning doing business. Saw Grace Elliot in afternoon, went to Baker St, Mme Tussauds. She is looking very well indeed. Saw Col Barraclough.
Entry.280:
Took letter of introduction to Memiton Dept Store gate, got passes to go over factories. Went to show at night.

23/2/18

Went to No 3 London General saw Capt Hall 20th who I left out on
Entry.281: He is still in bed but expects to be up & about very shortly. Went to No 4 took Grace to show & dinner. Had good time after. I am a flirt after all.
Entry.282: Sunday. Spent morning writing to Mum. Saw Percy Jones people in afternoon, 2 lovely little sisters, Katherine & Connie. Went over Hampton Court & Grounds of National Physical Laboratory. Had dinner at night.
Entry.283: Had letter from Mrs Harwood, sent souvenirs to Mr Jones & took 1.0 pm train to Paignton passed through Reading, Bath, Bristol, Taunton, Exeter, Torquay, arrive Paignton 6.40 pm, went to Esplanade Hotel saw Mrs Harwood & took a room. They expected a Telegram to let them know I was coming & were rather taken back.
Entry.284: Mrs Harwood is an extremely nice woman too good I think & accordingly very likely to be imposed upon. Went for a Motor drive towards Newton, there were 5 of us including Mrs Harwood’s boy, beautiful drive & took snaps of party. Had long talk with Mrs Harwood at night.
Entry.285: Went for a skate on Pier. Left Paignton 1.49 train for Chester via Exeter, Taunton, Bristol, Newport, Pontypool, Abergavenny, Hereford, Shrewsbury, Wrexham, Chester. Arrived at 9.0 pm. Had walk round Town.
Entry.286:
Caught 9.15 train to Queens Ferry saw over the factory, met Allison who used to be in Chem Lab. Dumbley & Dilly. They make H2SO4, HNO3, Guncotton & TNT. H2SO4 from S.A. pyrities burnt at temperature of 5-600° SO2 passes, together with dry air forms SO3, through H2SO4 acid absorbes

3 in all varying from 92-98% H2SO4. 98% best absorber & takes up from 20-30% SO3 get H2SO4 by dilution.

HNO3
 from Saltpetre NaHO3 from Chili carted in trucks to factory unloaded in dumping shed conveyed by overheads pulleys in iron baskets to a grinder & then heated in revolving drum to remove organic matter, cooled, taken & put into retorts with = part of strong H2SO4, sealed down & heated for 10-20 hrs at 160°, fumes pass into condenser & collected, distilled to strengthen. Vats & pipes of iron.

Guncotton
 Cotton waste brought in bales to factory put through shredder & then through teaser until very fine, taken & placed in porcelain O tubs & covered with acid 2 hrs, acid run off & water on until strong acid

has gone (2 hrs), drained, taken in overhead trolleys to washing room, placed in O aluminium tub holding 25 bucket loads = 1 ton, washed with water steam bubbling though for 12 hours, water renewed by running in cold from bottom another 12 hrs & then 3 six hour washes, acid test with N/2 NaOH, Methyl orange , after each wash usually free after third, taken away & packed. Guncotton thus produced is low in N. values & is soluble in C2H5ON & ether. Sent to Gretna for cordite manufacture.

T.N.T.
 made from mono-nitro-toluene, received from foil companies, pumped into tanks & then charge together with mixture of HNO3 & H2SO4, di product forms easily at 60° in couple of hours. di product rises to top, pumped into higher retort. A fresh acid added heated to 110°

after 6 hours action complete, run off acid from bottom & then T.N.T. comes out of pipe met by stream of cold water, T.N.T. crystallised & falls into bin, water drained out & T.N.T. carted in trucks to refining room, put into retorts again washed with boiling water 1st & then with 10% solution Na sulphide turns red, run off, washed with water (acid to litmus) separated again, passed over hot plates to get rid of moisture, run into cold revolving drum, crystallises, packed in boxes of 45lbs net, stored in magazines of 1000 boxes. Na sulphide only used for special purifications navy & fuses etc. Returned to Chester took 9.45 pm to Carlyle via Crewe arrived there 3.0 am put up at Station Hotel.
Entry.287:
Left by 10.0 train for Gretna. Saw Head Office, car took me round to Nitro Glycerine. Car at my disposal all day, had lunch & tea with head, treated very well indeed. Saw Wright & Eastaugh. In addition to acids & guncotton they make Nitro Glycerine, cordite & ether.

Nitro Glycerine
 from Glycerine by action of HNO3 in presence of Sulphuric, 40 HNO3, 60 H2SO4 acids mixed, put into retort, Glycerine run in keeping temperature at 12° cooling done by CaCl2 at -12°c. tri nitration goes at once 2 hours, run of Nitro Gly, boiled with NaOH to neutralise acid, washed 2 with boiling water, & then a measured quantity run over gun cotton. Have now mixture of Nitro Glycerine & Nitro Cellulose, taken to next shed, sieved & again bagged.

Cordite
 product from Nitro Glycerine plant is put into mixture with Alcohol & mixed, after 15 minutes mineral jelly added, after 15 more stirring Ether added, stirred for 4 hours, becomes stiff paste, taken out squeezed through sieve, muslin & then forced out through bottom of cylinder into threads, these are cut into = lengths, taken away, dried in Houses for 60 hours & then further dried for 3 days, products of drying sheds taken away & Ether & alcohol recovered by forcing vapours through cresol making alkaline & distilling.

Ether
 made by fractional distillations of mixture of Alcohol, H2SO4 & water in prop 7:3:1. Alcohol added continuously in form of vapour enters through holes at bottom of retort & by time it comes to top is 60% ether 

efficiency of plant 97% theoretical value from Alcohol. Girls working about 1000 all very healthy, gay & well fed & looked after. Gretna Town is newly put up & Hostels are provided for female & male workers, all cooking done at central cookhouse, food distributed & reheated at separate branches, everything clean & well run. Have never seen such a healthy & happy lot of girls, all dressed in coat & breeches & go about with both hands in their pockets & if no pockets down the top of the trousers. Several portions of both T.N.T. & Nitro Gl works are in 3 distinct parts joined by tram lines. Finished by 5.30 pm returned to Carlisle, stayed night.
Entry.288:
Left by 10.0 train for Edinburgh, country covered in

snow looked very pretty, very rugged right up to Edinburgh, went through Carstairs, arrived at 2.0 pm, stayed at old Waverley Hotel. Had look round city. Visited Mrs Mill but she was out. City built on 2 sides of Valley, railway lines at bottom, so decent shops not very large & a few theatres. Left by 10.0 train for London. Had sleeper Naval man all companion all way down, came through Newcastle, York, Bedford.
Entry.289: Arrived in London 9.30 am, cold & misty, went to Hotel found letter from A.I.F. H.Q. saying for me to attend investiture last Saturday (yesterday). Also two from Grace, she has Tuesday night & Wednesday off. Bon. Visited Dover House Rockhampton but Jhonnie Weedon was out had hurt his leg falling down stairs.
Entry.290: Strolled round town in the morning went to Bank no more money though. Saw matinee Chu Chin Chow & at night The Boy at the Adelphi, both very good.
Entry.291: Went to Greyhound Road, A.I.F. Kit Store. Looked at kit bag. Got photos from Australia House 1/- a print, some very fine proofs. Had tea at Simpsons with Grace went to Opera, Faust at Royal Theatre, Drury Lane.
Entry.292: Met Grace 12.30 pm went to Simpsons & then to Grafton Galleries to see war pictures. Very fine indeed all enlarged & photos. Went to a Mrs Brown at Earls Court for Tea. Saw Grace back to Hospital.
Entry.293: Left by 8.0 train for Dover, went down with Mackenzie 18th Batt & Rags Green. Had dinner in Dover, embarked at 12.30 pm. Stayed night in Calais.
Entry.294: Caught 9.30 train for Steenwerke arrived 1.0 pm walked to Camp. 2 Coys in Ingersoll & 2 in Nieppe. Walker in Command, Col Briers evacuated to Hosp with appendicitis very bad. Dad Boyden 2nd in command no coys in fusilier loop, move up to line about Wednesday. Percy Jones off to a school missed him. Atkinson back.
Entry.295: Went for a route march. Saturday ½ holiday, beautiful day, everyone talking about German offensive. Major Walker especially.
Entry.296: Sunday. Church service in morning at 17 Battn. General Smythe presented shield to 17 Battn for sports. Another beautiful day, sun quite hot again. Saw in Times that I had got a bar to M.C. hope it is correct, lost 3 bottles of whisky to Jhon Gray. He got 8 bottles in all.
Entry.297: Visited fron line with Niven (returned yesterday), Mac, Bill Cullen, Atkinson. Hot walk, front quite & disposition same as last time. A & B take front line first. Fritz shelled Nieppe. B Coy moves to LOe Rossignol, officers with us here. Bone of Battn hit or civilian casualties in all 14. 8 killed mostly 2nd Pioneers.
Entry.298: Drill during day, shelling going on most of the time. Good day, sun very warm, spend all spare time sitting in sun by the Huts without coat.
Entry.299: Went for a ride with Bill Cullen to Bailleue, Capt Sadler returned today, looks well. He has been away just on a yr.
Entry.300:
Left Engersoll camp at 6.30 pm moved up to Lancaster 4th A & B Coy in front line. Keith & Elfainstone doing patrols. Allan Reserve Direct night. Major Walker & all

heads seem to expect an attack, supplied one post to McMeekin in front line also carrying rations for him.
Entry.301: Arthur Mainstone encountered an enemy patrol last night. He is missing, 1 killed 7 wounded. Arishes takes over his patrol, the trouble was caused by the larteness of his orders from H.Q. thus not giving him enough time to properly detail his men.
Entry.302: Moved Coy to convent. Lane took H.Q. over from C Coy. Hinds & his platoon are in Unifire Support. Allan remain in same. Beautiful day. Shelled front line heavily also plenty of TM & gas, a Coy of 18th took over the farm.
Entry.303:
Another bright day, lot of our planes up, very few Fritz. Enemy shelled convent farm & H.Q. pretty heavily, 2 casualties. Had com with Major Walker over men available for

fatigues, told me not to be insolent. I did not take it lying down. Major Allan to Reading tench.
Entry.304: Visited Bill Cullen, Perryman was evacuated with gas this leaves Bill on his own.
Entry.305: A few shells, weather changed, raining constantly all day. Visited Capt Mac. All in good spirits. Katherine post report having seen a hun patrol, they fired & threw some bombs, got nothing, I am doubtful about the patrol. Lancet in charge of Katherine post.
Entry.306: Still raining. Wrote to Col Briers at No 5 British Red Cross Hosp, Winnergun. Also to Major Muting at Btn H.Q. he said of 18th Battn tonight on Bridge Head of Pont Range. Fitzroy captured a Hun about 11.30 pm.
Entry.307:
Raid a success no casualties but no prisoners. Fritz

had evacuated the post. Then our large No 7 gas shells. Had to wear helmets for some time. Relieved about 12.0 midnight by 26th Battn, moved back to Canteen Corner.
Entry.308: Cleaned up, had kit inspection. Good camp. Robinson & myself are in a cubicle with 2 beds & a good fire, very comfortable. Another room with Major Walker, saw him again at night but talked straight & settled through the night.
Entry.310:
Arrived back from visiting line at 6 am, line is a series of

posts separated by small gaps. Coy H.Q. good solid pill box about 100 yds from line. Had sleep & coy ready to move by 5.30 pm. Moved up to line via Neuve Eglise, Wulverghem , Messines, relief complete by 10.0 pm, took over from 58th Battn, visited posts.
Entry.311: Cold but fine, no movement by day. Slept nearly all day. Roby went round posts at night, troubled by T.M. & m.guns. Artillery very quite.
Entry.312: Same as yesterday, got dopy stopping indoors all day. Toby Hinds blown up by Minnies, one man slightly injured. Hinds slept in dug out all day.
Entry.313:
Rained a little. C Coy post raided at dusk, 2 killed, no prisoners on either side. T.M.’s still busy in guns, make things very lively, we are on top of hill & Fritz is below he gets

us on the skyline like at Le Sars.
Entry.314: Arthur Keech blown in this morning, got 3 sigs buried dug out 2 have ribs broken & one is badly crushed, got them out at dusk. Relieved by B coy at 10.0 pm, moved back to reserve at Messines, have large comfortable dug outs, most of them have furniture inside.
Entry.315: Visited H.Q. & learnt that a raid was to take place on night of 31/3/18. I had to volunteer as O.C. raid & took 1 platoon from both C & D coys out that night to a place called Bristol castle for training. Have 2 officers & 60 men. Keech & Andrews who knows Nancy Johnson. Billeted men in dugout & then returned to Messines.
Entry.316:
Parade at 9.0 am & started training raid in 2 parts closing in on a pill box in afternoon, went to details camp

saw Boyden & Sadler on return meet Brigadier & told that raid was off as a relief was in progress that night. Returned with men to Messines. Andrew stopped with men in Castle.
Entry.317: Spent quite day had good O.P. close at hand & can see Commines, Wervicq, Armentières, Warneton etc quite plainly. Visited by some officers of 19th English Division who are relieving us, these people were in front opposite Bapaume during the last hun push, did not have such a bad time. One does not know what to believe our communiques are unreliable.
Entry.318: Another good day. Fritz doing very little shelling, indeed a few Minnies only, relieved by 19th Div, marched to Le Rossignol Camp near Kemmel, arrived there 2.0 am.
Entry.319:
Arrived camp ay 2.0 am, left again in motor buses at 7.0 am

moved to billets between Godeswelde & Flêtre very cramped. Moved again as loading partyto Godeswelde station.
Entry.320: Loaded transport all night entrained at 8.0 am & travelled to St Roche near Amiens arrived there 10 pm very cold, marched through Amiens to Cardonette arrived 1.30 am.
Entry.321: Arrived 1.30 am. Had something to drink slept like a top until 11 am. Had breakfast. Left village at 2.0 pm embussed & moved to Bussy-Lès- Daours. Coy Commanders reconnoitred the front & on return moved Blangy-Tronville via Daours, Vecquemont.
Entry.322:
Arrived at Blangy-Tronville 1.0 am. Hard list of sleep in tumble down shanty, place full of soldiers, moved again at 4.30 pm for front line. Gentilles, Cachy relieving a mixture of Berkshire, 6th Londons & Welsh Fusiliers. No guides

arrived so had to wander about with the company, find the posts & relieved those in my sector.
Entry.323: Relief completes by 3 am, men dug themselves in & I made a H.Q. for myself in an old pit. In morning visited H.Q. The country is all plowed fields, very few shell holes & in the early part of the day no sniping but later on it got pretty hot. On my return from H.Q. I had a rough trot with snipers.
Entry.324: B Coy attacked the Bois de Hangard this morning in conjunction with the 20th, up to date very few details are to hand but it seems McDonald & Bignell have been killed. Dos Wallack wounded. All round Coy H.Q. were shelled heavily today, some falling very close. Men keeping well.
Entry.325:
Rainy day but quite. Some of the men visited Villiers-Bretonneux & brought back a lot of food, wine & clothing expected

to be relieved tonight but disappointed, casualties to date 34. Shells village of Cachy consistently only have a few details there & R.A.P. Fred Lipscombe wounded.
Entry.326: Feet very sore & bit damp otherwise all OK. Have bit of a cold mostly effects of gas, relieved by 34 Battn at 10 pm, moved back to Boues. Village deserted & our billets were cottages very well furnished & in most cases contained cider & wine, ours was a Laundry, slept in a bed with clean sheets & a womans chemise. Had fowls for dinner.
Entry.327: Breakfast 11 am, spent most of day in training. Round village houses have been left in a hurry only things of value taken, furniture, clocks, etc left intact.
Entry.328:
There is a big attack coming off. D Coy will be attached to 20th Battm, our job is to establish a strong post at S.E.

corner of Hangard wood. With Col Bennett getting final orders he is an old woman.
