Entry.329: F.M. shells fell today, knocking the houses opposite puts the wind up one very thoroughly, men very comfortable all have stoves in their billets & are doing their own cooking. All arrangements for attack cancelled. Fritz attacked & captured Hangard, retaken by the Essex & French. He has also attacked up North & taken Armentieres, Phoegsterst, Neippe & Steenwerck were shelled. Out of billets at 6.o p. Billeted in a field. Had 4 casualties 2 killed & 2 wounded.
Entry.330: Moved at 8.0 am to open near Gentilles dug in alongside a bank, we managed to get a shelter erected by the engineers. A Coy moved up to the support line.
Entry.331: Cold wind blowing, put in a fire place. Had as many officers in Hut as it would hold, fire was the attraction.
Entry.332: Another cold & windy day, left Billets at 7.0 pm, moved up & took over from Small of the 17th. Took over same front, lot of shelling of rear areas, quiet on front line.
Entry.333: Cold day, few aeroplanes up. Fritz constantly uses our planes to fly in. support Battn heavily shelled in the morning, driven out of their position in front of Gentelles.
Entry.334: A great no of gas shells probably 10,000, were thrown into Bois L’Abbe at dawn & dusk, visited by an officer of the 2/4 Londons taking over from us tomorrow night. Took him round posts. Had 5 men gassed in village of Villiers-Bretoneaux. Honey from village, also wine & tinned vegetables.
Entry.335: Relieved by 11.0 pm, moved back to a wood 2000 yds rear of Gentelles, reached there 1 am.
Entry.336: Has some stew & then slept night with Keech. Cold, rain. Cleaned up in morning as best we could, wood full of French colonials from Africa. Moved at 2.0 pm to Pont-Noyelles via Glisy, Dauors. Had billet there deserted house very comfortable.
Entry.337: Cleaned up & left again at 1.0 pm, marches via Frechencruss, Behencourt to Montigny where we billeted, one room for the five of us, not bad, some civilians still in place. Other Coys not so well off.
Entry.338:
Reconnoitred forward area with Sardler, Stortley & Cullen. Had dinner at 5th Field Amb. Brick now Colonel & has gone to take over Southall Hosp, returned to Montigny.

Had tea with Justileus, saw Diamond in 104 How battery. Fritz plane over at night. Lillie returned & in B Coy.
Entry.339: Beautiful day. Had parade, instructing lewis gunners, trying to get enough gunners to carry six guns. Saw R.C.A. Anderson, went for ride with him to Bussy, saw Jackie Beith, R.M.O. to 57 Battn. Dos has lost his left leg. Had a good nights sleep.
Entry.340:
Inspected by Birdwood this morning, gave the usual speech. Left Billets at 3.0 pm, moved to Warloy via Beaucourt & Contay. Saw some of the old people in Contay who were there last June. In all the villages the people are overjoyed at the Australians coming there & are satisfied to stay. They have great faith in us & very little in the Tommy. Heard that Dos

had died.Belcher, L.S.Jones, Sid Sell, Fleming & Pearce have rejoined the Battn, good to see some of the old faces back again. Sent forward as advanced party Jock Fisher & 20 O.R.
Entry.341:
Had everything ready to go to the line when orders cancelled. Villers-Bretonneux taken by the Hun & we are likely to be moved south to retake it. 12 & 13 bgs have gone south, standing by in billets ready to move at any moment, did not move.

25/4/18

Settled down again, got our valises back, wrote letters & squared up. Villers-Bretonneux retaken with 700 prisoners, very fine stunt by 4th Div &
Entry.342: Div, came right in behind Hun.
Entry.343:
Will move up to the line tonight, troubled with gas

in company have 43 cases, 8 bad ones, took at least 6 days to show up. Left Billets in Warloy 7.45 pm, moved up to reserve line via Henencourt. Reserve line about 900 x from front line & is on top of a ridge running between Millencourt & Senlis. Dug all night building a H.Q. Jock Fisher is with me.
Entry.344: Albert is in full view, the Madonna & Child has been knocked down by one of our own batteries about middle of April, we shell town heavily all day. The La Boisselle ridge can plainly seen also Becourt & Fricourts roads, the old rest camp still stands at the top of the hill, make one fell rather disheartened to think Hun is in possession again after having cost us so much to take. I don’t see how we can possibly retake it. Fine day, no movement during daylight. Walker threaten to shoot anyone who moves round H.Q.
Entry.345: Did some more work on our home, it is know 6 ft deep & 8’ long & 6 wide, quite comfortable for here, sheets of iron for a roof. Fisher Skeech went out on patrol, nothing doing, front very quite.
Entry.346: Rained a bit during day but dug out quite dry. Artillery officer up in line doing some shooting, our guns shoot day & night but lot of gas put over by our 4.5 how, approx. 250 rds, a battery per night. Allan Skeech did patrols.
Entry.347: Drill day. Artillery officer with us, no observation during day, too foggy. Col Walker has not visited us so far. He got as far as B Coy & on return rang up Bge to let them know that he had been round.
Entry.348:
Quiet day, relieved at night by 22nd London Regt, look a good lot. Officers came in with Sam Browns on

on etc, done up like some fingers neither sensible or comfortable. Relief complete by 10.30 pm, moved back to Warloy. Rec letters from home.
Entry.349: Arrived about 1.0 am. Had a good fed & sleep, parade at 10.30 am, rather a shock inspection by Col Walker, moved to Montigny 12.45 pm via Vadencourt, Contay Beaucourt. Billeted in Maire very comfortable, A Coy opposite. Have small room to myself.
Entry.350:
Parade, went for route march & did some drill. 
Afternoon ½ Holiday
 went out reconnoitring with Col, defence lines, weather beautiful.
Entry.351: Saturday, kit inspection & more reconnoitring, rather pleasant riding round. Visited 20 Batt H.Q., saw old Norman Bennett of 20th.
Entry.352: Sunday, moved to Allainville via St Gratien, rained all the way, arrived 11.0 am. Had to search for Billets, got fixed up at last. Village very crowded with soldiers, likely to be here for a few days. Had game of Poker with B Coy, came out square. Slept well.
Entry.353: Fine day. Paraded on lewis guns all day, men very interested, progressing well. Have a
Entry.354:
Battn officer attached, Harries, but he has been sent to 20th & Brown from 18th here instead. Kennery has come to me. Brown is I.O., rather dirty on Col part I think. Had game of Poker won 50 frcs.

7/5/18

Should have done a practice stunt op wood but cancelled owing to rain. Chateau in this village owned by Hennessy (3 star man). Lewis gun instruction in billet,

drilled in afternoon.
Entry.355: Beautiful day, drill in large paddock near billet, a pity that a war should be on these days, wrote letters to next of kin of those men buried at Villers Bretonneaux of 36th Btn, also one to Rials people.
Entry.356: On Courts martial all day, did 19 cases. Battn moved to La Houssoye via Quissien & Pont Noyelle, were shelled out of village about midday & Bivouacked for night in Bois Escardonneuse. Hun was still shelling village when I arrived at 9.30 pm, slept well though a little cold.
Entry.357: Moved up to line before Coy to have look over. Coy brought up by Allan got bit of gas on way up. I came via Heilly Mericourt, line in front of Morlancourt,
Entry.358:
in support, 18th in front line. Quite in front shell & support Battn 3 rear areas.

11/5/18

Quite day can move about at Coy H.Q. Tremercy Skeech out on digging job, making c.t. from front to support line. Had wind up tonight, a 6 horsed waggon got caught in barb wire, went out to offer advice & Fritz opened out, waggon drew back & so did I at the trot, felt rather ashamed afterwards.
Entry.359: Few shells over now & again throughout the day, some gas at dark shells Marret wood consistently, nobody there, also an old concentration camp at edge of wood. Fisher & Allan out on another C.T. job on 17th Battn front.
Entry.360: Bit cloudy & rainy, dug out, quite day though smells a bit full of slugs, cleaned up by night party out again. Letter from Grace,
Entry.361:
Fine day. Had clean up, water pretty scarce. Had good

look at surrounding country, can see Demacourt, Edge Hill rest camp, Buire, Millencourt, Sanicville, Breshe, Honencourt, Basiena, Franvillera, Tahouisaye, Mericourt, Riberment, Heilly, Areux, & Ville-sur-aucle & Albert. Visited line with Starkey in the afternoon.
Entry.362: Another good day, sunbaked all afternoon, one gets annoyed that there is a war on days like these. Starkey will probably get a D.S.O. for Hangaard Wood stunt, our planes go over 20 – 30 at a time & bomb his Horse lines & billets about Heaulte, each carry 4 – 6 bombs & can be heard falling in salvos, planes higher up go further over, same process goes on all night.
Entry.363:
Had sunbake, visited H.Q.’s Bill Cullen, Sadler, Storky & Doc. Bill is looking bad, spoke to Doc about

him. Get a wonderful view from B Coy H.Q.’s, on other side of Somme Canal. All country up to Villers Bretonneaux. Battn is very weak, my company is nearly twice as strong as any of the others & I am only 10% O.R.
Entry.364: Should have relieved 18 Btn in front line tonight, postponed a stunt by 6th Bg coming off. Had game of Poker with Hunter, Fleming, & Allan until 1.0 am, whiles away the time.
Entry.365:
18th had silent stunt today. Irvine took 20 men in daylight, ambushed a Hun post, a complete surprise, took 2 in gun & 23 prisoners. D Coy has to dig C.T. in conjunction with 18th Battn. Reconnoitred position of C.T. to be dug from front line to man posts. Good position to dig should go well. The Battn order I got was no good they seem to make them

 

up, as a matter of routine giving no thought to the situation at all. Had to make my own arrangements.

19/5/18

Left trenches at 12.15 am arrived at support line our starting point, dumped surplus gear & ready to move by 1.30 am, moved forward in rear of 18th Battn at 2.5 am, went along C.T. to front line, were C.T. was to begin & found that trenches in front was still occupied by the Hun. Engell the Engineer Officer went out to lay the Tapes & was held up by a Hun post. I sent Fisher & 6 men out to him to rush the post & at the same time started putting the men on to the tape. The post was rushed capturing 2 in gun & 6 prisoners, the total we got altogether was 15. I think that the effect of lining the men out put the wind up the Hun, & made Jock’s task easier.

We dug until 6 am & then I sent men back to support trench. Col Murphy was out there at 8 am, at 9.0 am I moved down to a bank & shortly afterwards the whole company arrived. Here they could get dry & clean off the mud. Wonderful to relate since no casualties in the Coy. A.S.B. Selby was hit however carrying. Built good dugout in the bank & spent a good day. The gun 19th Bn relieved 18th in front line, I stayed where I was but moved 13th &
Entry.366: Battns back to trenches in rear.
Entry.367:
Basked all day, the sun very pleasant, indeed saw Col Fisher near Col & Major Walker is back to major. He seems alright though one cannot tell immediately. Ruck took out patrol. Patrol order from Battn gave wrong map references & impossible to carry out, orders

are not much good when you are unable to take any notice of them.
Entry.368: Slept until 1.0 pm. Percy Jones paid Trenery & myself a visit. Bill Cullen inactivated the day we moved up to here. He has been very bad for some time. Supplying a digging party for A Coy tonight.
Entry.369: Sunny day, washed myself & shirt. Had a long spin this time without a change. Newton Mortas fired a few shots at extreme range 1425 yds. Rec Grace’s photo.
Entry.370: Quiet day, dull & rather cold. Men reported to B Coy for duty, rather disappointed at leaving company. Chapman & Brand have been evacuated from B Coy, Chapman has lost an arm.
Entry.371:
Good mail tonight, 5 letters from home, the offensive got Mum down a bit, but all seems well, expect to hear that I am an uncle again.

25/5/18

Saw Kaippel & Hobbs of 18th. Hobbs has been back to Aust & says same as Doyle that one is not wanted. Kaippel was attached to one of the British Div during the retreat & he says that they fought splendidly. 47th Div relieved by 18th Battn at 10.30 pm & moved back to original support line. I expect to leave for T.B. on the
Entry.372: Hope I do go, a change will not come amiss.
Entry.373: Sunny but not very warm. Visited Starkey, he has T. Captaining A is recognised to be getting a V.C. Hope it is but it makes one a bit jealous. Human nature I suppose.
Entry.374:
Warm day. Hun threw over a lot of gas from 9.30 – 11.30

in the valley, caught our parties, got 70 of ours & 80 of 18th, can ill afford to lose them at the present time.

Keech gassed in trench, seems alright in afternoon, inspected bridge. Heads had tea with Pioneers in Heill, have some billet.
Entry.375: Keech evacuated, very bad, carried away, Fisher eyes are sores but not bad. Col Briers returned to the Battn. Forbes still in command, no parties.
Entry.376: Whole Coy went for a bath, in 2 & 3’s, got them away & back safely. Saw Col Briers, looks well. Visited all Coys to say Good bye, leaving for T.B. tomorrow.
Entry.377:
Said good bye to Coy, Murray said he was sorry that I should go so must have made good though the last few months it has been an effort to visit the line & do

my job properly. Left Coy at 12.30 pm & proceeded to Bg at Tsully with Doohan & Wilesmith. Got passes & went back to Transport lines near Pont Noyelles in a mood & very pretty. Doohan will not be able to come with me. Had a good wash & slept well.
Entry.378: Got into decent clothes. Rode with Padre to St Gratien to get some money, said good bye to Col Murphy in wood & he complemented & thanked me for the work I had done in the stunt. Don’t know if he did any recommending. The more one gets the more one wants. Saw Irvine & Bill Graham. Robertson brought a draft to Q.M. Store but returned himself to Muclem.
Entry.379:
Left by lorry for Ailly-sur-Somme at 7.45 am, went via Amiens outskirts, no train until 6.15 tonight. Had walk

 

along canal bank, met Pickford who was Frank Burke’s batman. Caught the train & arrived at Boulogne at 1.0 am.
Entry.380: Went to officers club, had something to eat but all beds full so slept on a sofa, up at 6 am. Caught noon boat, arrived Folkestone about 1.30 am & London 5.0 pm. Booked room at officers club 138 Piccadilly, had walk in park. Hepburn of 23rd was with me & we looked that brown that people turned round to see who we were.
Entry.381:
Spent day in London. Saw Grace in afternoon, had run out to Kew Gardens, she looks very nice but thin, has been on night duty for w mths. A man does not know what to do, either go home single which would give more pleasure

to his people or to get married. If war keep on for a few more years I think that it will be a case of marriage.
Entry.382: Reported to Horseferry Road, told to catch 1.0 pm train for Fovant, did some shopping & caught the 5.0 pm arrived alright at 9.0 pm. Eva Gordon, Sgt Watts, Levin & Morrison were there & carried my gear up, slept in Padre Green’s cubicle, he being away on leave. Saw George Peden & Jack Bach, who is gas officer here.
Entry.383: Reported to Col Norrie, greeted like a lost friend saw Bge & gave Staff Capt letter from Col Freliers. Still probably get administration school alright. Had game of Tennis in the afternoon with Ernie Read, too good & Browning of 20th. Bit out of practice but not bad.
Entry.384:
Capt of duty. Had to inspect camp in Divisional

area, inspected camp, YMCA & canteen, finished by 12.0 noon. Rest of day to myself. Had game of Tennis.
Entry.385: Dull & bit rainy, not allotted to any definite work yet had look round the Bull ring, very few men working. Camp can accommodate something like 6,500. At present in camp about 700 & no more in sight, what few were here have gone to 4th Division. All reinforcements now coming over as general. I heard that 300 men from Australia came over as officers to R.A.F. under conditions that if they did not pass the tests they would be returned to Australia. 11 out of 300 passed, rest were returned, another disgrace, those that are left seem to have lost all their manly qualities.
